item.title: Remove the Friction - Morning Coffee #28
item.content:encoded:
The number one obstacle to forward motion in any endeavor is friction.

We expend a lot of energy to overcome the friction in our lives, but we tend not to do much to remove the friction altogether.

We set goals, we develop discipline, we push and push and overcome, but think how much further we'd go, given that same amount of energy, if the friction was reduced by half?

I have experienced this in so many different ways and across so many years that it's become extremely clear to me:

Friction is like putting a governor on your car. It's an actual limitation. It may not limit the destination itself, but it can make it MUCH more difficult and time consuming to get there.

I think most of us can point to the major sources of friction in our lives. Negative people, overbearing bosses, government regulations, etc. And there are plenty of people talking about how to handle that friction. Get rid of negative people, quit your job, find somewhere else if your government won't allow you to do your thing.

But the friction that is the most damaging in the long term is the friction that is more subtle. It's less obvious, less dramatic.

For example:

1. Do you BELIEVE you can do what you're trying to do?

2. How do you FEEL about your ability to perform?

3. Are you providing yourself with the resources you need to feel positive and believe in yourself?

4. Do you KNOW where the friction is coming from?

5. Are your actions yours (or are you living out someone else's ideal)?

Take it from me, these "hidden" sources of friction slow you down way more over the long term than the more "dramatic" sources.

Ask yourself those questions and seriously answer them. It might seem "woo-woo" or "hippy-dippy", but I promise if you find those hidden sources of friction and get rid of them, you'll notice the difference.
item.excerpt:encoded:
The number one obstacle to forward motion in any endeavor is friction.

We expend a lot of energy to overcome the friction in our lives, but we tend not to do much to remove the friction altogether.
item.dc:creator: bretmartineau@gmail.com

item.title: "There's No Money In Music" - Morning Coffee #29
item.content:encoded:
I came out of high school really wanting to go into music education. I wanted to be a choir teacher at some junior college somewhere, and eventually get the opportunity to conduct a university choir.

And I was GOOD, by the way. Still am, although I'm out of practice.

But somewhere along the line, I let someone convince me that there was no money in music.

And from that moment on, it became "clear" to me that the right choice was to pursue law, and leave music behind altogether.

At the time, I figured I knew enough about how life worked that the decision to abandon the music and do law was the "right" choice.

If only I knew then what I know now.

It's not that I regret where I've ended up. I am really happy with my life. My experiences have shaped me into who I've become.

But I can't help but wonder whether I'd have become a better version of myself if I'd stuck with what I wanted to do.

The truth is, there was no possible way for me to know how my choice back then was going to work out for me.

But I was CONVINCED, not only that I was making the right decision, but that it was the ONLY right decision.

And since then, I've been in so many situations where I've been absolutely convinced that something is true, only to find out later that I was completely mistaken.

We can't really know anything for certain - the math is too big.

There are way too many variables to consider for us to actually think we can predict any outcome.

And yet we do it all the time. We make decisions based on these "informed" hypotheses that are really just uneducated guesses.

No matter how convinced you are of something, life will show you an angle you weren't expecting.

Best thing to do is exactly what you want - because whether you choose the "wise" or the "foolish" route, the net result is the same:

You get some things right. You get most things wrong. Life beats you down, and then you have a few amazing moments.

item.title: The Responsibility of Having an Opinion is Expressing it Honestly - Morning Coffee #30
item.content:encoded:
I've always resisted the idea that you should keep your opinions to yourself when it will rock the boat or cause conflict.

I really dislike the idea of censoring my actual thoughts and feelings for the sake of some arbitrary standard of "peace".

I just don't think we have time for that.

Whether we allow ourselves to believe it or not - our time is limited, and every moment of growth that we waste by hiding our actual opinions and thoughts is a moment we can never get back.

And worse than that - training your mind to tell little white lies (regardless of the motive) changes the way you think. Before long, NOTHING YOU SAY is true. Everything you say to everyone becomes the rose-colored (false) version of events.

I think we're afraid of not getting everything perfect every time. And we're afraid of the messiness. You can't predict everyone's opinion or their reaction to your opinion, so if everyone starts being honest, things can get really messy.

But life IS a mess. There's nothing clean or neat or predictable about it. So why are we trying to convince ourselves it should be anything but messy?

If you think something - you have a responsibility to the collective of humanity to express it. Or at the very least not try to pass yourself off has having a different opinion.

We as a whole, and you as an individual, WASTE opportunities for growth when we're not fully, openly, and bluntly honest with ourselves and others.

So take some responsibility, own up to your opinions, and embrace the mess.

I really dislike the idea of censoring my actual thoughts and feelings for the sake of some arbitrary standard of "peace".

I just don't think we have time for that.

item.title: The Agency That SHOULD Exist - Morning Coffee #36
item.content:encoded:
So I have this vision for an agency that would solve a MAJOR problem for freelance web talent (copywriters, designers, developers, marketers, etc).

The inspiration for this agency comes from a few different places:

1. Hired Gun (on Netflix)

This movie is all about the studio musicians that often are the workhorses behind the popular musicians that we celebrate.

This movie tells the story of some of the greatest musicians alive who just happen to be better at literally playing second fiddle to the more popular names, and therefore we don’t know who they are.

In some instances, the “hired guns” were directly responsible for the success of a certain song, because they suggested specific changes to it or provided an iconic instrumentation for it, and yet we still don’t know who they are.

Some of them, in fact, are struggling to make a living, even though they should be listed right alongside the major artists that are making millions off of their hard work.

I immediately felt a kinship with those musicians, because I (and hundreds of others like me) have generated billions of dollars in revenue for others, and yet some of us struggle to make rent payments each month.

There is obviously a lot that I could unpack there, but suffice it to say, I started thinking of myself and others in my similar position as “hired guns” in the same way that these musicians are.

2. Episode 293 of the #AskGaryVee Show (with Michael Ovitz)

On this episode, Gary and Michael talk about how CAA (Michael’s talent agency) took Hollywood by storm by completely changing the way that studios interact with agencies.

Instead of simply representing individuals (actors, directors, etc), Michael started bringing complete projects to the studios. He’d round up a cast, the writer, the director, and the other pieces of the puzzle and presented that to the studio with a budget, and then they’d make the movie.

I might be misquoting that slightly, but that’s what I remember, and that’s what struck me. Because of Michael and CAA, the major studios no longer had to do the legwork of putting the movie together, they just had to pay for it.

And that was better for everyone involved. Michael’s team was representing the talent, so they were more interested in preserving the artistic nature of the projects, where a studio executive might be quick to shut down an idea or theme because of budget, legal, or other restraints.

So the talent wins, because they’re represented by someone who has their best interest at heart, the studio wins, because they don’t have to waste time putting the projects together (which they’re not that good at anyway), and CAA wins, because they get to work directly with everyone, creating relationships and opportunities for virtually unlimited future projects.

There is so much gold in this episode, I could go on for pages and pages, but for now I’ll just say that this episode sparked the notion that there could be one central agency that negotiates complete packages for business owners, so one contract could include the campaign builder, the copywriter, the designer, and anyone else that’s necessary, and they’d all come together for that particular project.

3. Season 1 Episode 3 of The Romanoffs (Amazon Prime)

First of all, this is a great show. I highly recommend it.

In this particular episode, there is an actress who is hired to play a part in a TV show, and she’s flown in for the on-location shoot. It’s immediately apparent that she is very particular, and being a popular actress, she is used to getting her way and having things just so.

She butts heads with the director, and eventually it gets to the point where she doesn’t want to be part of the show anymore, and calls her agent.

The thing I found particularly interesting is that her agent accepts the task of getting her out of that predicament, something that I didn’t realize agents do. Now, I’m not sure that is actually true, and the episode actually leaves it a bit ambiguous as to whether he really would get her out of that situation should it arise, but it got me thinking.

Sometimes the relationship between expert and business owner can get off track or flat out untenable. The problem is, the experts (or the talent) don’t have the time or the desire to deal with those kinds of situations. I know I’ve been in that situation enough times to know how much of an energy suck it can be, but if there was someone else who was truly incentivized to have my best interest in mind and get me out of bad situations (or at least help with explaining what was happening), I’d be more free to do what I’m actually good at, instead of always having to switch back and forth.

So - My Vision

My vision is to create an agency that sits between the implementers and the business owners and facilitates the entire process, enabling the business owner and the talent to spend their time where they should: on the actual project.

The cool thing is that also creates opportunities to educate and empower the talent with training courses and programs, as well as standardize the rates and ratings of everyone providing the services. It’s the wild west right now, and it’s about time to establish some law and order in the industry.
item.excerpt:encoded:
Life as a freelance digital marketing expert (campaign builder, designer, copywriter, developer, etc) is not as lucrative as it seems.

We love to talk about our exorbitant hourly rates, but the truth is, we only charge that much because we are limited in the number of hours that we can actually bill at those rates.

There is so much time and effort that is wasted trying to find new business, and the deck is pretty much stacked against us.

I have a vision for a way to solve that problem.
item.dc:creator: bretmartineau@gmail.com

item.title: Certification (it's just a piece of paper) - Morning Coffee #32
item.content:encoded:
Do you have a college degree? What about an industry certification?

Did you notice that it’s possible to get either of those without really knowing anything about the subject matter?

Or, conversely, remember that scene from Good Will Hunting, where he tells the Harvard student that he wasted $150,000 on an education he could have gotten for $1.50 in late fees at the public library?

In truth, college educations and industry certifications are unfortunately not synonymous with competence or expertise. There are enough examples of people who achieved the accolades but don’t have the first clue about the subject matter,.

And there are plenty of people that have real-world expertise in those matters that never bothered pursuing either.

That doesn’t mean there’s something wrong with getting a degree or certification - in fact sometimes those things are necessary to advance your goals.

But it’s important that you not consider them as anything more than what they actually are:

Pieces of paper.
item.excerpt:encoded:
Did you get a college degree? Did you take exams for industry certification?

Do you value that degree (or certification) more than the experience of getting it?

Truth is, a degree (or certification) is just a piece of paper.
item.dc:creator: bretmartineau@gmail.com

item.title: The Wife, The Mistress, and The Vice - Morning Coffee #37
item.content:encoded:
What I’m about to share with you is the result of many, many years of life bashing me over the head trying to get me to understand this simple principle.

I am not someone who enjoys saying “No”.

I don’t like thinking (or thinking that someone else is thinking) that I’m not capable of doing something.

I say yes to everything, because I see every request as a challenge, and I don’t back down from challenges.

The unfortunate side effect of this is that I get spread very thin very quickly. And my lizard brain gets so focused on accepting every challenge that it forgets sometimes about some of the simpler challenges that it’s already accepted.

I don’t know if you can relate to this at all, but it’s genuinely frustrating for just about everyone involved.

Scratch that, it’s frustrating for everyone involved.

Not too long ago, in an extraordinarily uncommon flash of lucidity, I realized that a HUGE part of my problem is that I was treating my “work” life differently from my “home” and “personal” lives.

I realized that while I put a lot of effort into building out systems to keep track of everything I was supposed to do for my clients, I wasn’t doing the same for simple tasks or projects that myself and Sue were undertaking.

I also wasn’t really setting goals for my personal life in the same way that I was for my clients or even my own business.

And because I had these different “systems”, I was effectually multitasking between task systems (how’s that for meta?).

All of that would have meant basically nothing, except I remembered an article I’d read back in 2006 published by the American Psychological Association about how multitasking is just switching back and forth between things, and it has an immense psychological cost.

It hit me like a train.

Switching back and forth between “task management” systems for the different parts of my life actually had a cost!

I wasn’t able to perform at optimum in any of those areas of my life because I was wasting too much energy switching back and forth between how I managed that part of my life!

So I did what any sane, reasonable person would do in that situation: I dumped all of my ideas out on the table to try and sort them out.

I realized something right off the bat.

There were too many things.

If I was going to get anything done, I needed to trim the fat on these projects and ideas.

And there was a lot of fat.

The first thing I had to do was let go of many of the little “hobby” ideas that I’d kept on the back burner because “you never know”.

I just looked through all of those ideas and plans and put them in order from “I don’t want to die having never accomplished this” to “Meh”.

Things like going back to law school, starting a band, writing a novel, starting a virtual staffing agency, teaching music, and teaching Russian didn’t make the cut, because I had other things that I wanted to spend my time on more.

I realized that the things that I was most passionate about, that I really didn’t want to give up, were these (in this order):

  1. Sue (and the bear, of course)

  2. Muay Thai

  3. Music

  4. Marketing (only because it’s my only viable source of income)

The really cool thing at this point was that the things that I was really passionate about all in different “categories” (except music and Muay Thai, which were both hobbies).

As I was considering this list, it occurred to me that a person might really only be able to maintain 1 major “project” in each area of life. I looked at this list and it was clear - even if I let these 4 occupy 100% of my waking time, I still probably wouldn’t be able to do any of them justice.

So that made closing the door on my other ideas really easy.

Ok so what’s all this have to do with wives and mistrisses?

Let me explain:

I really like metaphors, and as I was thinking about this cute little list of things that I had chosen to do, I came up with this one:

A man, at any point in his life, can have one wife, one mistress, and one vice.
And I’m not talking about marriage or infidelity, this is a metaphor.

The Wife

A man is loyal to his wife, he comes home to his wife, eats dinner with his wife, and works day in and day out to support his wife. His wife represents everything that is steadfast in his life. She is there for him when he needs her, and most importantly, he is committed to her enough to work on their relationship. If things aren’t great, they go to counseling. If there are problems, he talks them out with her. He wants it to work, and everything he does (well, almost everything), is to ensure that the marriage succeeds.

 

The Mistress

However, the man sometimes gets restless and turns to his mistress. He doesn’t love her, but she provides a much needed (and short lived) release from the steadiness of the wife. He is not committed to his mistress. If there are issues with the mistress, he can leave and find another. The mistress is fully aware of this, and is not looking for anything more. It’s not to say that he can’t fall in love with his mistress, but then she becomes his wife and some other “strumpet” takes her place as the mistress.

 

The Vice

In other cases, the man needs a break from women altogether. He needs something that doesn’t require any other person, and that he doesn’t have to share. His vices are for him and him alone. He doesn’t abuse them, because he understands that overindulgence will make him soft. He partakes when he needs to, and then returns to his wife.

 

These three (wife, mistress, vice) occupy all of the man’s time and energy, but the balance of the three keeps him satisfied, refreshed, and motivated to do what he needs to do. He needs all three to maintain that balance.

He works hardest on his relationship with his wife, because it drives his passion.

He toys with his mistress, because that is what “tickles his fancy”. 

He indulges in his vice, but sparingly so as to not spoil it.

Now we do the wrap-up

I believe that each of us can realistically handle 3 “projects” at a time. The first (the wife) is the singular project that gives us purpose and provides meaning for life. 

The second (the mistress) is whatever pet project we are entertaining at the time, whether it be a new service, a side gig, a hobby, or an actual mistress. 

The third (the vice) is the project that we do just for ourselves. It could be blogging, writing poetry, playing poker, building a cigar collection, or becoming a sommelier. Sometimes a hobby can start as a vice, then become a mistress, and eventually you put a ring on it and it becomes your main focus. 

So consider this for your life:

What represents “The Wife” for you? “The Mistress”? “The Vice”?

Let me know in the comments below:
item.excerpt:encoded:
People (myself included most of all) often make the mistake of thinking that they are capable of handling anything that comes their way.

The truth is, a person can really only juggle three things at once:

The Wife, The Mistress, and The Vice.

item.title: Facebook Ads on a Fixed Budget - Tech Tips #1
item.content:encoded:
If you’re running Facebook ads, you probably don’t have an unlimited budget. (side note - if you do have an unlimited budget, my hat goes off to you. also, you should give me some)

The problem with being on a limited budget is keeping track of how much you’re spending across the various campaigns that you’re running, not to mention the posts that you’re boosting.

However, there’s a little hack you can use to make sure that no matter what you do, your monthly ad spend will always be the same.

Here’s how you do it:

1. Consolidate Your Campaigns

The first thing you need to do is create 3-5 campaigns, organized by preferred outcome. 

You may end up with more or less campaigns depending on whether you release video content. You’ll want to have a campaign for each type of content. So if you have videos, you’ll want a campaign optimized for video views. If you have blog content, you’ll want a campaign optimized for content views (viewContent). If you have content that is intended to get someone to take some action outside Facebook, you’ll want a campaign optimized for conversions. So, assuming you release videos on a regular basis, these are the campaigns you’d have:

  1. Awareness (optimized for brand awareness)

  2. Video Engagement (optimized for video views)

  3. Content Engagement (optimized for viewContent)

  4. Action (optimized for conversions)

2. Campaign Budget Optimization

The next thing you need to do is set all of your campaigns to optimize the spend at the campaign level:

You can set each campaign to a limited budget of as low as $2/day (around $65/mo). That would total out to $8/day across all 4 of the campaigns (or $260/mo). 

3. Configure the Campaigns for Cold and Warm Audience Targeting

Within each of the above campaigns, set up ad sets to distinguish between target groups. I normally have 3 ad sets per campaign:

  1. Warm audience rollup - basically anyone that has engaged in any way (watched video, clicked to website, liked/commented/shared post, etc)

  2. Cold lookalike rollup - all of your lookalike audiences combined.

  3. Cold interest rollup - targeting based on interest only (no custom audiences).

I also like to make the audiences mutually exclusive, so I’ll exclude my lookalike audiences from the Warm and Interest rollups, the Warm Audience from the Cold Rollups, etc.

And now for the secret sauce.

4. Add New Content To Existing Campaigns

Now, when you release new content, instead of boosting the post individually, simply add it to the existing campaign based on the type of content and who should see it.

So if you release a new video intended for your followers, here’s what you do:

  1. Navigate to the Video Engagement campaign

  2. Select the Warm Audience Rollup ad set

  3. Click “Create” to create a new ad

  4. Select “Use Existing Post”

  5. Select your post

  6. Publish

The really cool thing is that it doesn’t matter where the post was originally released (Facebook/Instagram), because it can be promoted on both platforms at the same time (assuming the video isn’t longer than 1 minute).

The wrap-up

Setting up your campaigns this way will help you organize your content by use, but more importantly it helps you keep your ad spend predictable. Instead of creating a new campaign for every post, you’re simply using the campaigns that already exist, and adding the content to those.

On a regular basis, it’s a good idea to go back through and disable the content that isn’t performing as well, so that you can make way for fresh content.

Thoughts, feedback, questions? Drop them in the comments below!

item.title: Light - Foto Friday #1
item.content:encoded:
This photo was taken at Balboa Park in San Diego. I was at the park playing badminton of all things, and I turned to see a man with his Australian Shepherd playing fetch with a frisbee.

Wick hadn’t joined our little family just yet, and being as obsessed with Aussies as I am, I was mesmerized.

A photo can’t really express the feeling of being in that spot, watching that happen, but it’s the next best thing to it.

The way the light filtered through the tree while the dog sprinted back and forth on the grass was something else.

I don't think truth matters nearly as much as we tell ourselves it does.

It does, however, give us a nice excuse to ignore our very real emotions by bottling them up until they inevitably explode, destroying most of what makes sense in life.

item.title: Just do it
item.content:encoded:
Brad was very much into sports, which I think has a lot to do with his attitude about work. In sports, there's not a whole lot of actual thinking that you do. Obviously you have to think about what you're doing, but philosophizing on the way the basketball net represents life isn't going to help you make baskets. I think that's why I wasn't ever that good at basketball. I just over-thought everything. It was especially bad with baseball. You can't hit home runs by thinking too much. You think too much, and you'll miss the pitch every time. Anyway, back to Brad. Being so into sports, Brad was quite obsessed with Nike. I remember one time we were on vacation and Brad really wanted to go to the mall because they had a huge Nike store there. He loved Nike. Interestingly enough, the slogan, "Just do it" stuck with him I think, and kind of became his motto for life. Just do it. When I finally figured this one out, I looked back and realized how much time I'd wasted trying to get out of things. I wasted more time and energy avoiding responsibility than it would have taken to just do whatever it was that I was supposed to do.

Take making the bed for example. My whole life, I would try to do make my bed as quickly as possible and expend the least amount of energy possible. Or doing the dishes; I would make up all kinds of excuses, and just wander around until someone else did the dishes and then I'd come waltzing in at the end to make it look like I'd helped. 

A huge part of this lesson is coming to the realization that you are not entitled to anything. So often we grow up with the notion that we are entitled to the good things attached to good actions, and so if there is no benefit for us, we don't do it. Welcome to the real world, people. Entitlement is as bogus a principle as any, and so many of us refuse to do the simple things in life because we don't think they will bring us the satisfaction we deserve. Once you realize that you really aren't entitled to anything, you realize that the real reason for doing things is because you are responsible for them. I do the dishes because they are my dishes, not because it’s my turn to do them or because I think I'll get something from doing them. I make the bed because it's my bed and I am responsible for it. I just do it.

I really wish I had understood this principle in high school. Back then I thought I owned the world, and I figured I could do anything that I wanted. I didn't study in high school because I didn't think that I needed to. I finished high school with a fairly good GPA, and I studied for 1 test the entire time. I had decided that I didn't need to study because I could still do well without studying. It was just a waste of time for me to study, or so I thought. If I had just studied, then I would have saved myself the two semesters of college that I totally bombed because I didn't really know how to study. If only I had just done it.

I could go into all kinds of examples about this principle, but I think I've made myself clear. I think in general, if you find yourself not wanting to do something that you know full well is your responsibility, and you hear yourself saying things like, "but I don't need to do that," or, "but that's boring," or anything like that, JUST DO IT!
item.dc:creator: bretmartineau@gmail.com

item.title: We like because, but we love even though
item.content:encoded:
Many times I’ve heard in movies or from friends or acquaintances phrases such as, “I just don’t love him/her anymore because of this thing he did,” or “I put up with his habits when we first got married but I just can’t stand them anymore.” The general theme is that one cannot love another unless the other is doing everything right all the time. So much of how much one person loves another is tangled up in what the other person does. Let me give a few examples to show how this line of thinking and feeling is absolutely bogus and does not work in real life.

Example #1

When I was serving a Mormon mission in Ukraine, part of my responsibility as a missionary was to love the people. Without an unconditional and real love for the people, I would have been ineffective and unhappy as a missionary. (I realize that this example may strike some as not applicable, but the point is that I needed to love them, and it could have been for any reason.) At first I found it difficult to love the people because as a general rule everyone drinks and smokes, and much of the time they do both at the same time. Not only this, but the culture there is intensely promiscuous, and so I had to struggle a lot with very forward women who sometimes could not see past the fact that I was an American boy with an American passport that somehow could get them to America if they were to impress me in a sexual way. These and many other factors made it nearly impossible for me to really love them, because they were doing so many terrible things all of the time, or so I thought.

As I matured in the mission and grew into the work more, I came to realize that I was no longer disturbed by the constant drinking and smoking, and I found creative ways to avoid awkward situations with the women. The constant distaste that I had for them began to wane, and I realized that the more I worked to serve them, the more I grew to love them. I was out on the streets or knocking on doors or chatting with people all of the time, and before too long, I realized that I loved every person that I saw or met. To this day, I have a deep love for the Ukrainian people. I have come to see a deep strain of very admirable and loveable characteristics that are pretty much intrinsic in all Ukrainians. There are still things about Ukraine that I don’t and will never miss, but the people of Ukraine I will always miss.

It turns out one way to really love people is to forget what they are doing and focus on what you are doing. I would submit that at least 80% of the time, if you find yourself blaming someone else for your lack of love for them; it is mostly your fault. Let me say that again. If you are blaming someone else for the fact that you don’t love them anymore, it is more than likely that it’s your fault.

Example #2

Before my wife and I were married, we had some couple friends that were at about the same stage of dating as we were. It happened to be the case, however, that many of the relationship difficulties that every couple must go through were hitting us about two weeks before it would hit them. Now, this couple will know who they are when they read this, so I hope they don’t mind me using this story, but it applies universally I think. About once every couple of weeks, the guy in this other relationship would come stay the night at my place and the girl with Naomi at her place. In almost every instance, they both had some fairly serious frustrations with the other, and so it was good for them to have some time away with a slightly more experienced couple (and by that I reiterate, about two weeks more experienced) with whom they could discuss what had happened. I remember quite clearly that almost every time, the frustrations of each individual were with something that the other had done or was doing, and neither of them were able to see past that. The amazing part for me was that I could see in both of their faces how much they actually loved each other, regardless of what was actually going on in the relationship. When they talked about breaking up for a little while, I could see on both of their faces how little they really wanted that. When they would talk about how it might not work out and they might have gone their separate ways, I could see both of their hearts breaking, and one of them even started crying when it was brought up. The point here is that with their eyes and their opinions, they were overlooking what their hearts knew very strongly. They saw what seemed to them to be unsavory qualities and bad habits, and in their opinions, that seemed to make the decision for them. But all along it was written all over them how much they deeply loved each other.

Once they realized for themselves how much they really loved each other, and saw past the little irksome habits, they knew that they only wanted to be with each other, and they were married a few months later. They still have tiffs and little skirmishes, but they realize now, at least to some extent, that love is not about what the other person does, it’s about how you feel when you are doing everything you can for the other person. Love isn’t about expecting affection; it’s about learning to work.

Example #3

My wife and I have been married for almost nine months now, and if there is one thing that I have learned, it’s that she really must love me, because much of the time she really doesn’t like me. I can be quite hard-headed sometimes, and sometimes I say and do things that you just shouldn’t say or do, ever. The worst part is I’m also a very proud person, and tend to defend myself to the very end. For those of you more experienced husbands, you understand the folly in that, and for you less experienced husbands, shoot for humility early on. My wife, however upset and frustrated she is with me at any particular time, which on average is a little to mildly upset, has never even hinted at leaving or threatened me in any way. She just goes about her business until I wisen up, which I do sometimes, and apologize to her. Now, I know I’m not perfect, and I know that my imperfections are the bane of my wife’s existence, but she is constantly looking past those stupid things that I do and trying to make things better because she knows the difference between liking and loving. I can attest to the fact that my wife does not always like me. Sometimes she does, but I’m a bit of an egg-head and so it’s not surprising that she would find occasion to “fall out of like” with me. However, she has never even hinted that she was falling out of love with me. For that I am always grateful, because I know that I love her more than anything, and if she was to give up on me, I’d be up a creek.

I use these particular examples for a couple of reasons. First, the main point here at first seems to be that you have to look past someone’s faults in order to really love them. This is absolutely true. If you can learn to look past peoples faults, you will find your capacity to love increases a hundred-fold.

My real point, however, comes from a quote that I heard a while back. I don’t remember who said it, but I think regardless of its origin, it applies. “You know you’re really in love with someone if you have encountered their faults and you still want to spend the rest of your life with them.” I would take that a step further and say that if you know someone’s faults and you want to be with them on the condition that you are able to change some of their faults, give it up now. Such relationships are doomed from the beginning. You must know their faults and be perfectly willing to be with them forever even if they only change a little bit or in some cases not at all. Obviously if their faults are going to lead to really bad a place, that’s a different story, but if someone has faults that are going to lead them there, get out of the relationship!

My conclusion is this. First, in general, learn to look past people’s faults and see them for who they really are, not a bundle of mistakes, but a human being no better or worse than you are. Second, when looking for someone to spend your life with, be sure that you are comfortable with everything about them. Do not expect to change them, because you will not be able to! Be wise, however, and understand the difference between a real deal-breaker and a stupid pet peeve. Third, once in a marriage relationship, never lose sight of the fact that you love the person you are with. Every single married couple on that has ever been, with the possible exception of one (but we don’t know enough about that to say anything) has gotten into fights over dumb little habits that one or the other has. Don’t think that it’s the end of the world or your marriage because of a fight. Learn that you can still love someone and not like them at that particular time.

Love is not something that comes and goes like the fleeting wind. That is like. We like people because they do things that we enjoy. We love people even though they do things we don’t like. Know the difference.
item.dc:creator: bretmartineau@gmail.com

item.title: There’s nothing quite like family
item.content:encoded:
So I just got back from what I'm going to refer to as the first ever Stan & Susan Martineau Family Reunion. It was a little bit weird for me, since at every other family reunion that I've been to I've been one to the grandkids, or great-grandkids. At this one, I was one of the uncles, one of the second generation, not the third or fourth. The other weird thing was that it wasn't so much a reunion as much as it was a retreat, although since I came from Utah, it was kind of a reunion. Anyway, let me get to the point.

On Tuesday of last week, my parents came back to the states after a 3 year 'term' in Puerto Rico, where Dad served as the president of one of the missions there. Needless to say, it is very nice to have parents again. I've essentially been without a mother and father for the past 5 years almost, since I had been in Ukraine for a while before they left. I'm going to be honest, life without parents is no good. I've had a lot of substitutes for parents, like brothers and sisters, my wife, and my in-laws, but nobody can really hold a candle to mom and dad. I can't really express accurately in words (or any other way for that matter) how amazing it is to know that they can be mom and dad again.

Another reason why it is so nice to have mom and dad back is that all of us kids can be the children again. While mom and dad were gone, all of us had to sort of step it up and be more 'responsible' because mom and dad weren't there to be the 'responsible' ones. I don't know if I can really describe it, but it seemed like as soon as they got home the brothers started wrestling again, and the sisters started acting like sisters and not co-chairs of the Martineau Committee. It just seems more like the family that it used to be back before I left for Ukraine 5 years ago. I've missed that a lot. It's nice to have it back.

Now I'm sitting on my in-laws' couch thinking back on the trip and realizing that I really wish that it had never needed to end. Mom and dad just got back, and now I have to go back home to Utah and miss out on all the Sunday get-togethers and the random weekday lunch trips to Gecko Grill with everyone. Especially knowing that mom and dad are planning to serve another mission at the end of this year, it just makes leaving right now that much harder.

I love my family, because that is the only place, the only organization or group, where things don't really change. My place in the family is always the same, and I never have to worry about trying to be anything but myself. I don't have to be smart or athletic, I don't have to have the best ideas or do the smartest things, I don't have to be the best at anything, because my family makes it abundantly clear that they love me just the way that I am, and will keep loving me no matter what. That is security that you just can't find very often these days.

I'm on the verge of going back to real life, and I really don't want to take the plunge. I've just had the best 4 days since I left for Ukraine 5 years ago. I really don't like for things like this to have to end. Why is it that they always do
item.dc:creator: bretmartineau@gmail.com

item.title: The very next day
item.content:encoded:
Wednesday was not a good day. Thursday didn't start out too well either. Then something amazing happened:

But first, as always, back story.

About a month ago, I went to a meeting that the Russian department put on to talk about their study abroad/internship program in Moscow. I'll be honest, I mostly went for the donuts, but during the course of the meeting, I was suddenly convinced that I needed to go to Moscow and do this internship. Went home and talked to the wife about it, and then was assisted in realizing that we absolutely could not afford for me to go. And we really couldn't.

Fast forward to about Monday of this week. I had finally committed myself to the idea that I'd focus on school and law, and let Russian be a hobby for the rest of my life. I was ok with that, too. I was settling into the new direction that I'd decided to take my life, and it actually felt nice.

Now fast forward to Thursday (starts out crappy, like Wednesday was). It's the middle of the day, I'm just sitting somewhere trying to figure life out (first mistake) and I get a call from one of my Russian professors. He tells me he has a proposition for me. He says that they usually take a grad student to be the assistant program director for the study abroad/internship program. That position is a lot like a fellowship, and the person team teaches with the professor, teaching the 100-level students that go. Most of those students are the spouses of the other students that go; most of whom already speak Russian. Because the assistant program director helps teach, they are paid by stipend, and their program costs are covered by that stipend, as is airfare. Then he tells me something that makes me almost start crying immediately:

He told me then that the grad student that was set to go had to back out unexpectedly. Then he said that he recommended to the department that I take the place of the grad student as the assistant director, and that another two of the Russian professors seconded the proposition and they agreed to offer me the position. Now, I realize that there seems to be little reason to get emotional about that, especially for me, a person who rarely, if ever, gets emotional. But this was special to me. After spending weeks thinking that nobody cared about me and that nobody thought I was good for anything, here are my professors recommending me to take the place of a graduate student. I can think of at least 5 other students in the Russian program who are much better Russian speakers and writers. I am definitely not the most qualified for the position, but for some reason these professors decided to recommend me. After the week that I'd been having, I think you can understand me getting a little emotional. It meant a lot to me that somewhere, not under my control, someone thought of me in that way, and spoke highly of me. I didn't ask for anything like this, and yet it happened.

I don't know if I can adequately describe the feeling. It was a good one; I guess that's all that matters.

I don't know if I'll actually be able to go. I'd love to, of course, but there are things with graduation that I have to figure out. Apparently BYU gets picky about changing things once you've hit 90 credits, so I have to go talk to an advisor and make sure that I could still graduate if I were to go. But regardless of whether I go, just knowing that those men though highly enough of me to recommend that I take the place of a graduate student meant the world to me, and pulled me the rest of the way out of my slump. (Yes, those of you that sent me messages regarding Wednesdays post got me a little of the way out of it. Thanks)

Life isn't all perfect and peachy now, but I sure feel a lot better.

Is it interesting to anyone else that this all happened the day after I posted my apology?

item.title: Is God subject to Morality?
item.content:encoded:
This is a paper I wrote for a philosophy class:

The relationship between deity and morality poses interesting questions. Which of the two influences the other? Does either other exist only because of the other? Or do they exist entirely separate from each other? I will focus on answering these questions. In particular, I will show three things: First, based on the contradictory results of the alternative options, deity must determine mortal morality. Second, some higher code must influence deity in the determination of morality. Third, this theory still applies even if deity does not exist. Using these three considerations, I will show that although there must be some moral code to which deity is subject, deity is the sole source of all moral law to which we mortals are subject; morality as we are subject to it is the result of divine command.

I will use the example of murder to show that morality is established by deity. In essence, I will show that, no matter the relationship between morality and deity, murder is only wrong because deity has decreed it so. First, I will consider the three options regarding the relationship between deity and morality: (1) morality is under complete direction of deity, (2) deity is subject to a higher moral code, and (3) morality and deity are separate from each other. Next, assuming each of these options independently, I will show that murder, which is all but universally accepted as morally wrong, is only so because of the prescription of deity.

The first option is that all morality is under the complete direction of deity. In other words, that which is right or wrong is only so because of divine command. The result of this is that morality is entirely arbitrary, because regardless of the fact that deity did make right and wrong what they are, it could have been otherwise. It could be argued that deity could have reasons for giving particular commands. However, if all morality is under the direction of deity, then the only reasons which can influence deity in the determination of morality are purely rational, with no moral considerations whatsoever. Otherwise, there would be some moral principle or code which influences deity, which the initial premise shows cannot be the case. It is clear that under this option, murder is only wrong because deity so commanded it. If morality is completely subject to the direction of deity, then any act which is wrong is only so because of deific direction. Therefore, if morality is entirely subject to deity, then it must follow that the immorality of murder is determined by deity.

The second option is that morality is higher than deity, and so deity is entirely subject to it. If this is the case, it would follow that it is outside the power of deity to break that moral code in any way. Any deific action contrary to any instance of that higher moral code, including deific sanction of the act, would therefore be impossible. If it were possible, in the literal sense, for deity to contradict, directly or indirectly, a higher moral code, then one of two options must hold; (1) either the higher moral code is not actually binding on deity, in which case we are actually still operating under the first option, or (2) deity would have to be capable of ceasing to be deity. I will not consider the first option as I have already done so. The second option requires further explanation. I will explain this concept, drawing on Thomas Nagel’s reasoning in the eighth chapter of his book, The Possibility of Altruism.

If deity were capable of ceasing to be deity, then we would have to accept that the present deity (that which exists as I am writing these words) is somehow dissociated from the future deity (that which exists as the reader is reading these words). This brings with it unfortunate and contradictory results, the first of which is a requirement that deity is subject to time in the same way that we are, which is widely accepted to be false. The accepted notion that deity operates outside of time requires that deity not be capable of relinquishing those deific qualities and ceasing to be deity. If deity exists outside time, then every dated interpretation thereof would have to reflect the same exact being or entity, because regardless of the point in time at which the interpretation is made, the reference is made to the same metaphysical entity. Therefore, it cannot be the case that deity is deific at one point in time, and at another point in time, loses its divinity. Otherwise, we would be able to assert two equally true, yet contradictory, statements about the same entity. In other words, it would be possible to say of the same entity that it is at the same time deity and not deity. Therefore, if there is a higher moral code, then at the risk of ceasing to be deity and creating these contradictory results, deity would be incapable of acting in contradiction of that code. (57-76)

I will now assume that murder is an instance of that higher moral code. If murder is a part of the higher code, then deity would be incapable of murder or the sanction of murder. However, deity has not only sanctioned murder, but commanded it. Nephi states very clearly, “I was constrained by the Spirit that I should kill Laban” (The Book of Mormon 1 Nep. 4:10). Nephi doubted this command, and was hesitant to comply, but “the Spirit said unto me again: Slay him” (1 Nep. 4:12). Nephi then murdered Laban. So in this case deity was able to act in contradiction to the higher moral code that murder is wrong. Therefore, by application of modus tollens, murder cannot be part of the higher moral code to which deity is subject. This does not prove that deity is not subject to any sort of code, however. This simply shows that murder cannot be part of the code to which deity is subject, if there is one. Therefore, if murder is not part of a higher code, then the wrongness of murder has to come directly from deity.

One could raise the objection that there could be other instances of the same higher moral code which negate the wrongness of murder in this instance. In other words, one could argue that there are exceptions to every rule. However, it does not seem reasonable to me  that the higher moral code, to which even deity is subject, would be ridden with exceptions in this way. If that were the case, then there would have to be some way of determining which exceptions are considered valid for each of the moral laws, which seems to presuppose one of two things: (1) that there is an even higher entity which directed deity to direct Nephi to kill Laban in this instance, or (2) that the higher moral code is written down somewhere with each exception spelled out. The second option presupposes the first, and is only included to illustrate the absurdity of assuming that the higher moral code would or even could include exceptions. Exceptions to any rule presuppose an authority to which one can appeal for direction in the application of those exceptions. Allowing for this kind of authority which is higher than deity entails an infinite regress of higher authority, and therefore an infinite regress of deity. Incidentally, an infinite regress of deity is simply a more convoluted way to say, “Deity came first, so morality came second.”

The third option is that deity and morality do not influence each other. In other words, their respective influences over us come from altogether separate sources, and the influence of each does not reach far enough to affect the other. To illustrate, imagine two bank tellers whose booths are separated by a thick, soundproof wall. They are both able to communicate with you, the customer, but not with each other. They each influence you, but that influence comes separately, and neither is influenced by the other. Now, let us assume that murder is against the moral code, which we will place into the first booth. Into the second booth, we place deity. Now we will examine the implications of this option. This seems to resolve the problem of deity contradicting the higher moral code, because the moral code itself is outside the influence of deity. However, upon closer examination, we find this not to be the case. Let us examine the case of Nephi under this option. We can explain Nephi’s initial hesitation to carry out the command, as he had, in effect, the moral code telling him that murder is wrong from the first teller booth. Then, however, deity confirms the instruction, and Nephi kills Laban. So even in this instance, where it seems as though deity has no obligation to conform to any moral code, it is yet able to override the dictates of the moral code. Therefore, the moral code only exists insofar as deity does not command otherwise, or to put it differently, the moral code is only applicable until deity sees the need for a contradiction of that code. This can only be the case if, as in the first option, morality is under the complete direction of deity. In any event, under this option, the wrongness of murder lies at the discretion of deity.

Let us consider the implications of what has been shown thus far. First, either murder is wrong because deity so dictated or murder is wrong because a higher moral code so dictated. Second, even if deity is constrained by morality, murder cannot be a part of that morality by which deity is constrained. We are left with only one option: murder is wrong only because deity has so dictated. These preliminary findings bring with them a particularly implication that is prima facia disturbing. I will now focus my attention on resolving this concern.

Having shown that deity determines morality, we are left to deal with the accompanying concept of the arbitrariness of morality. This concept, as mentioned above, is quite disturbing in that it allows for a possible world in which deity determined morality to be opposite what it is in our world. This possibility is impossible to avoid in any option which asserts that deity is in complete control of morality. In order to rectify this seemingly irresolvable problem, we must consider two options: (1) morality is in fact arbitrary, or (2) there is some higher code which binds deity. It is important not to confuse the second option here with the second option considered above in regard to the relationship between deity and morality. In this instance, the higher code is not a set of morals which deity must uphold. Instead, it is a set of meta-morals or rules governing the creation of morals which sets the boundaries within which deity is free to determine the moral code of us mortals.

The first option is that morality is arbitrary. In other words, it is conceivable that deity, in some possible world, decided that rape, pillage, and cruel murder of children are considered right, and giving to the poor, saying kind words, and opening doors for women are considered wrong. This idea is understandably unsettling, as it undermines the entire idea of good and bad. If morality is entirely arbitrary in this sense, then one has much less motivation to act in accordance with the “good” which is provided. This is especially true if it turns out that deity does not actually exist. Instead of continuing to entertain this possibility, I will consider the second option.

The second option is that there is some higher code to which deity is subject. Again, this is not to be confused with the option already entertained that morality is higher than, and so directs, deity. The higher code to which I will now refer consists of a set of meta-morals which direct deity in the creation of morality. This code simply sets the boundaries in which deity is free to implement whatever moral laws are required. I assert that this code consists of two simple meta-morals: (1) good is an eternal concept which predates deity and (2) that which is to be considered right, or any consequence thereof must not contradict good. This concept resolves the issue of arbitrariness, because it dictates clearly that there are certain things which cannot be right, and therefore must be wrong. So where earlier we had to accept that in some possible world, deity could have decided that rape was right and kindness was wrong, we can now rest assured that a universal good does in fact exist.

This option resolves the arbitrariness problem, and also helps to explain the apparent discrepancy that I discussed in the first part of this paper. Although murder is only wrong because deity so commanded, the consequence of allowing murder as a permissible action would lead to a state of affairs in direct contradiction with the good, and so deity is constrained to proscribe murder in a general sense. However, because the proscription of murder is a law created by deity, deity is not universally constrained to uphold that law. This is especially true in instances where to not contradict that law would lead to consequences which would contradict the good. This turns out to be necessary, because it is the only way to resolve the contradiction of the “teological suspension of the ethical” (Kierkegaard), a concept which does not appear convincing in any way. If deity is constrained only to uphold the good, then it is well within the power and ability of deity to create general moral laws and break those same moral laws in individual instances. Therefore, the only viable option here is that there is some higher code to which deity is subject, and that code is simply to uphold the good.

I have shown that there must be some code to which deity is subject, lest there be unfavorable and contradictory ramifications. I have not shown that morality predates and therefore controls deity. There is a difference between the code to which deity is subject and the code to which deity subjects us. Deity is restricted only by the necessity that good be upheld. All other moral considerations are given to us by deity. This is the only viable explanation of the fact that deity can (and has) broken (and allowed to be broken) certain of those commands, such as the commandment not to kill. Hence, deity is compelled to uphold good, and therefore created a system of mortal morality that would best accomplish the goal of upholding good.

So why do we not worship this form of good instead of deity? In fact, many people do worship good in some form or another. However, these people fall into a similar category as those who believe in natural law theories and so in some instances break civil laws in order to not break what they call natural or eternal laws. These people feel that they are not subject to the laws given to them because they are connected to a “higher” law which supersedes the earthly law given to them. To “go over the head” of one’s immediate legal authority in this way is dangerous in that it undermines the authority of people to make and enforce their own laws. In addition, not every person has the same connection or interpretation of deity; if every person was accountable only to natural law, there would be no consistent system of laws, and therefore there would be no rule of law. The fundamental problem with this attitude, however, is that it is completely impractical. One can disregard the laws of one’s country in favor of natural law and still be imprisoned for breaking those laws. In such cases, there is no viable defense that can be of practical use; therefore, this attitude removes the personally perceived responsibility to uphold the laws of the land without removing one’s subjection to those laws. “Going over the head” of deity to worship that to which even deity is subject (good) results in a similar impracticality. While one could cite the higher law as reason for disobeying the dictates of deity, one would yet be subject to those laws to which one is subjected by deity. Therefore one cannot appeal to a higher authority than deity without fully appeasing the demands of deity. A problem which is even more basic than the impracticality of such attitudes is the incapacity of mortals to comprehend the intricacies and nuances of the application of good in real life. Our perspective is fundamentally flawed in that it is subject to our own experience, which is fundamentally limited by those experiences which we have not yet experienced. Deity is not limited in this way, and so our ability to understand and act in accordance with good is directly connected with our compliance with the direction of deity. Put simply, deity is in a position to direct our actions in accordance with good in a way of which we are not capable, and so we are necessarily dependant on deity to keep us in accordance with good.

One particularly formidable objection to what I have shown thus far is a popular objection when discussing divinity in any form: what if deity does not exist? It would seem that removing deity from the discussion in this way makes my argument all but obsolete and useless. If deity does not exist, then my initial premises have no grounding, and my entire argument falls apart. However, those who raise such an objection fail to take a crucial fact into consideration. In order to remove deity from the discussion, one would have to completely eradicate all mention of deity from all of written history. This is because even if there is no deity, the concept of deity which has existed at least since the beginning of written history has provided mankind with a moral code. As I will now show, there is no way to comprehensively show that there is some other source of our morality other than this concept of deity, and morality as we know it is completely derived from deity.

Since the beginning of written history, or more precisely since the first recorded human experience, deity has played a very large role in human life. In every culture, this is clearly visible. The Judeo-Christian concept of deity dates back to the first verse of the Bible, written by Moses, “In the beginning God created the heaven and the earth” (The Holy Bible, Genesis 1:1). The Greek polytheistic concept of deity is given by Homer in the beginning of the first book of The Odyssey, where he quickly introduces many gods (Homer). Other cultures have historical evidence of similar concepts of deity. All of these references to deity predate any recorded instance of atheism, which does not appear in history until the fifth or sixth centuries B.C., much later than these concepts of deity (Cline). Therefore, historically, deity predates atheism.

If deity, or at least a concept of deity, predates atheism, then it follows that the implications of deific existence predate the contrary considerations of atheism, in other words, deific law has influenced mankind for much longer than any other rational or ethical considerations. Today, the ethical philosophers debate over where morality comes from and where it finds its origins, but they all do so without considering the fact that the oldest form of morality in the world is this: obey God or suffer the consequences. Because deity has always advocated that people do good things, to one extent or another, it is not difficult to see that all of our present moral considerations find their primal derivation from a primitive concept of deity which predates all other ideas or concepts. In other words, all of humankind has based morality on that same primitive concept of deity which existed in the beginning. Therefore, to attempt to attribute morality to some other cognitive or emotional process denies the influence of thousands of years of written history. The fact of the matter is this: each of us learned right and wrong from our families and friends; society. Each of those people, in turn, learned right and wrong from society as it was when they were young, and so on. At some point, this retraction into history will end with a group of people learning right and wrong from someone who claimed that right and wrong are divine commands, and that disobeying them results in eternal punishment. Morality, as we know it, is based on a concept of deity which goes back much too far to simply remove from the discussion.

Because this concept of deity dates back to the beginning of written history, the ontological existence of deity is not really that important. In the same way that Santa Claus can influence billions of people every year to act a certain way regardless of his ontological existence, deity can influence morality regardless of the related ontology because the concept of deity bears that burden. All that is necessary for a person to be influenced by something is for that person to think that the something will affect her in some way, regardless of whether or not it will. Therefore, even if deity does not exist, the simple historical fact that a concept of deity does and has existed from the beginning of written history can accommodate for that fact (that deity does not exist) and still be the source of morality in our world.

I have considered the possible explanations for deific sanction of immoral action, and come to the conclusion that the only possible option is that deity determines moral law, for otherwise deity would be incapable of allowing immoral acts. I have also considered the possibilities associated with this initial conclusion, and concluded that even though deity decides the morality to which we are subject, there still has to be some code to which even deity is subject, lest morality be entirely arbitrary. I have also considered the objection that deity does not exist, and I have shown that even if deity does not exist, the historically accepted concept of deity can, independent of the existence of an existing deific entity, still be the source of all morality to which we are subject. These considerations result in only one conclusion. Deity is the sole source of all moral law to which we mortals are subject; morality as we are subject to it is the result of divine command.

Bibliography

The Book of Mormon. Salt Lake City: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1989. Print.

Cline, Austin. "Primitive Atheism & Skepticism - Atheism & Skepticism in Primitive Cultures".  About.com. 3-24 2011.

The Holy Bible, Containing the Old and New Testaments : Translated out of the Original Tongues and with the Former Translations Diligently Compared and Revised, by His Majesty's Special Command. Salt Lake City, Utah, U.S.A.: Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints, 1983. Print.

Homer, W. H. D. Rouse, and Copyright Paperback Collection (Library of Congress). The Odyssey : The Story of Odysseus. New York: Signet Classics, 2007. Print.

Kierkegaard, Søren, C. Stephen Evans, and Sylvia Walsh. Fear and Trembling. Cambridge Texts in the History of Philosophy. Cambridge ; New York: Cambridge University Press, 2006. Print.

Nagel, Thomas. The Possibility of Altruism. Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press, 1970.

item.title: The Other Shoe Always Drops
item.content:encoded:
This is the first politically-charged post I’ve made in a very, very long time. So it’s probably going to be terrible and you should leave now before I rot your mind with my ignorance and naiveté.

Ok, now that we’ve gotten that out of the way….

There is something deeply disturbing about this Brett Kavanaugh situation. And it’s not just the fact that he’s bringing shame on the his name (which, although incorrectly spelled, he shares with yours truly).

It’s not just the prep school entitled misogyny that we perpetuate with our constant rug-sweeping.

It’s not how many people I personally know that are engaged in the aforementioned rug-sweeping, quoting Ford’s hazy recollection and the “convenient” timing of the accusations - implying malicious, politically-fueled intent.

It’s not the widespread mockery being made of a sitting justice because of an adolescent predilection for drink, and what many consider his overly emotional reaction to the allegations.

It’s not the ridiculously opportunistic politicians that are using this situation as a platform to spew hysterics in the hope of garnishing further support.

It’s not even the overt hypocrisy being displayed by all sides of the situation.

What disturbs me most is how simple this is, and how we’re all missing the point:

Regardless of intent, all actions have consequences. Full stop.

Regardless of education, all actions have consequences. Full stop.

Regardless of understanding, all actions have consequences. Full stop.

Regardless of timing, all actions have consequences. Full stop.

(yes, I realize the 4 full stops are both redundant and improperly used. sue me)

Brett made a mistake back in college and it’s coming back to haunt him now. End of story.

The details of the mistake, contrary to popular opinion on both sides, are completely irrelevant.

Let me use a metaphor to explain my point:

In high school, we all learned about compound interest, and how if we saved $200 per month from the time we were 20 until we were 65, we’d have $67 trillion in the bank (my memory might be a little hazy on the details).

I understand that concept as clearly now as I did then, but I made a simple mistake. I spent that $200 each month instead of saving it. So my bank account is just a tad shy of the projected figure (by approximately $67 trillion).

Now, I could complain that I had a lot of circumstances that caused me to spend the money instead of saving it. I could explain that I needed that money for food, rent, gas, etc., but how much of that $67 trillion am I entitled to?

Zero. $0. None.

And you know what, all those reasons and excuses and rationalizations don’t make an ounce of difference when it comes to the question of my right to have that $67 trillion.

Because the plain truth is I made a mistake, and now I’m paying for it (literally). I can cry about it until the cows come home (or go away, depending on your preferences), but it doesn’t change the outcome.

In a similar way, let’s say I acquire a credit card with a fairly high credit limit. Let’s also say I’m not very good at budgeting, so I rack up a large amount of debt on that credit card, always with the full intention of paying it back, and always with the assumption that because the monthly payments are well within my income range, it will be fine.

Let’s say that after having accumulated all of this debt, I suddenly find myself with a vastly smaller income. I start missing payments, and the credit card company terminates my account. So now I just have a massive credit card bill, no income, and no way of using that additional credit to supplement my lack of cash.

Now I’m left with all the stuff I bought, no money, and no real way to pay it off. I start to get phone calls from debt collectors, collections notices, and the like.

I wasn’t using the purchasing power of that credit card for anything nefarious, on the contrary, it was used primarily on items to help others. I had the income to support the payments when I made the purchases.

What I failed to do was consider a future where the dynamic has shifted and I’m no longer in the same position. I made a mistake in a moment of short-sightedness, but my short-sightedness does not get me “off the hook” for the debt. Not in any way.

It’s the same with Judge Kavanaugh.

It doesn’t matter how much good he’s done since college. It really doesn’t matter whether he thought that she was “asking for it” or if she actually was asking for it.

The real problem is that we are so against people being held responsible for their actions, regardless of intent.

Brett should have been thinking about the future potential that he could sit on the Supreme Court when he was deciding on that extra drink or fooling around with the inebriated.

If I have to be held responsible for my choice to not save that money each month or to spend too much on a credit card, Brett Kavanaugh sure as hell better be held responsible for a mistake he made. Full. Stop.
item.excerpt:encoded:
This is the first politically-charged post I’ve made in a very, very long time. So it’s probably going to be terrible and you should leave now before I rot your mind with my ignorance and naiveté.

Ok, now that we’ve gotten that out of the way….

There is something deeply disturbing about this Brett Kavanaugh situation. And it’s not just the fact that he’s bringing shame on the his name (which, although incorrectly spelled, he shares with yours truly).

item.title: Handyman
item.content:encoded:
I got my start in Digital Marketing

back in 2004 at a little company called Infusion Software and Consulting, which you now know as Infusionsoft. When I started, the entire company (including the servers that housed all of the company data) fit comfortably into a 1500 square foot office.

[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="1600.0"] Infusionsoft Support Office, circa 2007 [/caption]

Since I left, Infusionsoft has created and provided many resources for its customers to help them learn and use the software profitably. But before there was Infusionsoft University, Implementation Accelerators, or Infusioncon, there was me. Just little old me, helping customers get more from the software.

In 2008, I left Infusionsoft and started on a path that would connect me with the best minds in marketing, technology, implementation, and strategy. Even more importantly, I would employ every type of “agency model” in existence, and would see first hand the effects of each.

From my time with SixthDivision and PlusThis to working directly with Frank Kern, I got a front-row seat to how these different models function. The thing that became glaringly obvious is that none of the models were set up with the customer’s long-term benefit as the primary goal. They were all set up to get the most money out of the customer while doing as little as possible.

Agencies Lose Money Delivering Services

[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="1936.0"] SixthDivision Booth, Infusioncon 2012 [/caption]

Agencies won’t tell you this, but it is not in their best interest to provide you services, especially when you pay for them. They don’t make money by providing services. They make money by selling services, and they profit from their ability to do as little as possible from that point on.

That’s not to say that all agencies are bad and you should avoid them, however. Some agencies have (at least subconsciously) recognized this innate flaw and have designed their services around it. I call these “Event-Style” agencies. They are the most up-front about the lack of ongoing service, and we are ok with it because they promise to make up for it with massive initial implementation.

The real issue with agencies is that they hold all the cards. They have the strategic expertise and the technical know-how, and you’re essentially at their mercy. You can only grow as fast as they can spare the resources for you.

But don’t I still need them?

Not really. It’s true, agencies tend to have a greater capacity than you, and usually have more experience and can shorten the learning curve and blah blah blah.

But the problem with an agency is they will sell you on more than you need so they can charge you for more than they should, all while making it appear that they’re doing more than they are.

No, you don’t need an agency.

You need a handyman.

What I Do

If it happens online, it's my expertise. I've been at it for over 15 years, and I've literally worked with every type of business. I've helped over 500 businesses solve the day-to-day, tactical problems which has helped those businesses generate over $250 million (that I know of). 

If you need help, all you need to do is text me at (858) 683-6814 and we’ll take it from there. But first, take a look at what some real people say about me:

Pick a time below to chat

item.title: Bio
item.content:encoded:
I’m Bret. I’m a Martineau, a marketer, a musician, and a Muay Thai fighter.

I’m also into writing, photography, dogs, and the Oxford Comma.

I believe life is about action. It’s about experiencing everything you possibly can and using those experiences to shape a better world for yourself and those around you. I think we’re all unique, so what makes me happy and gives me purpose may not be the same for you, and that’s ok.

     

I don’t believe in doing things simply because “that’s the way these things are done.” In fact, if you try and box me into someone else’s paradigm and expect me to just accept it, you’ve got another thing coming. There are no absolutes. Everything is meant to be tested. Just because something worked in one situation doesn’t mean it will work in all situations.

And lastly, I’ve spent a lot of time studying just about every philosophy and religion, and they all boil down to what I consider my personal mantra:

Don’t Be A Dick.

If there is any way I can help you, please don’t hesitate to reach out. You can text me (858 683 6814) or hit me up on any form of social media (@bretwardjames on all the platforms) 

Word,

Bret*

*yeah, only one “t”

item.title: Morning Coffee
item.content:encoded:
Morning Coffee

Daily LIVE Videos

 
Featured
Jan 7, 2019
The Wife, The Mistress, and The Vice - Morning Coffee #37
Jan 7, 2019

People (myself included most of all) often make the mistake of thinking that they are capable of handling anything that comes their way.

The truth is, a person can really only juggle three things at once:

The Wife, The Mistress, and The Vice.

Jan 7, 2019
Jan 4, 2019
The Agency That SHOULD Exist - Morning Coffee #36
Jan 4, 2019

Life as a freelance digital marketing expert (campaign builder, designer, copywriter, developer, etc) is not as lucrative as it seems.

We love to talk about our exorbitant hourly rates, but the truth is, we only charge that much because we are limited in the number of hours that we can actually bill at those rates.

There is so much time and effort that is wasted trying to find new business, and the deck is pretty much stacked against us.

I have a vision for a way to solve that problem.

Jan 4, 2019
Dec 6, 2018
Certification (it's just a piece of paper) - Morning Coffee #32
Dec 6, 2018

Did you get a college degree? Did you take exams for industry certification?

Do you value that degree (or certification) more than the experience of getting it?

Truth is, a degree (or certification) is just a piece of paper.

Dec 6, 2018
Nov 23, 2018
Just Some Funny Stories From My 3rd Stint at Infusionsoft - Morning Coffee #31
Nov 23, 2018

This starts out with me having to interview to get a job back at Infusionsoft. (Shout out to Scott Morrison)

1:15 - I am asked to stay at Infusionsoft for more than 2 years (I didn't)

Nov 23, 2018
Nov 21, 2018
The Responsibility of Having an Opinion is Expressing it Honestly - Morning Coffee #30
Nov 21, 2018

I've always resisted the idea that you should keep your opinions to yourself when it will rock the boat or cause conflict.

I really dislike the idea of censoring my actual thoughts and feelings for the sake of some arbitrary standard of "peace".

I just don't think we have time for that.

Nov 21, 2018

item.title: Privacy
item.content:encoded:
This privacy policy discloses the privacy practices for (http://bretmartineau.com). This privacy policy applies solely to information collected by this web site. It will notify you of the following:

  1. What personally identifiable information is collected from you through the web site, how it is used and with whom it may be shared.

  2. What choices are available to you regarding the use of your data.

  3. The security procedures in place to protect the misuse of your information.

  4. How you can correct any inaccuracies in the information.

Information Collection, Use, and Sharing 
We are the sole owners of the information collected on this site. We only have access to/collect information that you voluntarily give us via email or other direct contact from you. We will not sell or rent this information to anyone.

We will use your information to respond to you, regarding the reason you contacted us. We will not share your information with any third party outside of our organization, other than as necessary to fulfill your request, e.g. to ship an order.

Unless you ask us not to, we may contact you via email in the future to tell you about specials, new products or services, or changes to this privacy policy.

Your Access to and Control Over Information 
You may opt out of any future contacts from us at any time. You can do the following at any time by contacting us via the email address or phone number given on our website:

   • See what data we have about you, if any.

   • Change/correct any data we have about you.

   • Have us delete any data we have about you.

   • Express any concern you have about our use of your data.

Security 
We take precautions to protect your information. When you submit sensitive information via the website, your information is protected both online and offline.

Wherever we collect sensitive information (such as credit card data), that information is encrypted and transmitted to us in a secure way. You can verify this by looking for a closed lock icon at the bottom of your web browser, or looking for "https" at the beginning of the address of the web page.

While we use encryption to protect sensitive information transmitted online, we also protect your information offline. Only employees who need the information to perform a specific job (for example, billing or customer service) are granted access to personally identifiable information. The computers/servers in which we store personally identifiable information are kept in a secure environment.

Updates

Our Privacy Policy may change from time to time and all updates will be posted on this page.

If you feel that we are not abiding by this privacy policy, you should contact us immediately via telephone at (480) 455-2221 or via email at bret@bretmartineau.com.
